title: CBC "cut and paste" attack may cause Open Redirect(even XSS)
vulnerability_information:
Hello, Uber Security Team

I found an vulnerability in Uber URL redirect page.

# Vulnerability
In page
```
http://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?
```

parameter "EQ" is an encrypted URL and "Redirect.aspx" will redirect page to url which is decrypted.
After some trying, it looks like encryted by **CBC mode** and block size is **8**.

And I found an URL 
```
https://pages.et.uber.com/hangzhou1year/?uuid=1234
```

This URL can encrypted itself. For example
Access
`https://pages.et.uber.com/hangzhou1year/?uuid=1234`
and view the source you will see
```
https://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?
```
Above is the encrypted result of string `https://pages.et.uber.com/hangzhou1year/?uuid=1234`


# Exploiting
ok, now I can encrypt something by `?uuid=whatever` and decrypt something by `?EQ=whatever`

so I can decrypt all the cipher by `?EQ=whatever` (remember the padding...)

And I can create any cipher by **CBC cut and paste attack**
For Example, I encrypt `@orange.tw/?` and paste and cipher to bellow URL, when you access URL, you will redirect to orange.tw(my website)
```
http://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?
```

I think this vulnerability also can lead to XSS by creating an URL like
```
data:text/html base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K
```
if I have more time doing research ( it's evening in my country now :O )


# Attachments

`fake.py` is my Python poc
`2016-03-26_172607.jpg` decrypt the last block of cipher (%08%08%08%08%08%08%08%08 represented it use PKCS #5 padding)
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello, Uber Security Team

I found an vulnerability in Uber URL redirect page.

Vulnerability

In page

http://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?

parameter "EQ" is an encrypted URL and "Redirect.aspx" will redirect page to url which is decrypted.
After some trying, it looks like encryted by CBC mode and block size is 8.

And I found an URL 

https://pages.et.uber.com/hangzhou1year/?uuid=1234

This URL can encrypted itself. For example
Access
https://pages.et.uber.com/hangzhou1year/?uuid=1234
and view the source you will see

https://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?

Above is the encrypted result of string https://pages.et.uber.com/hangzhou1year/?uuid=1234

Exploiting

ok, now I can encrypt something by ?uuid=whatever and decrypt something by ?EQ=whatever

so I can decrypt all the cipher by ?EQ=whatever (remember the padding...)

And I can create any cipher by CBC cut and paste attack
For Example, I encrypt @orange.tw/? and paste and cipher to bellow URL, when you access URL, you will redirect to orange.tw(my website)

http://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?

I think this vulnerability also can lead to XSS by creating an URL like

data:text/html base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K

if I have more time doing research ( it's evening in my country now :O )

Attachments

fake.py is my Python poc
2016-03-26_172607.jpg decrypt the last block of cipher (%08%08%08%08%08%08%08%08 represented it use PKCS #5 padding)

activities.message: p.s. If you want PoC of XSS, I can write it tomorrow :P
activities.markdown_message: p.s. If you want PoC of XSS, I can write it tomorrow :P

This is PoC of XSS

http://pages.et.uber.com/Redirect.aspx?

activities.message: Hey @orange - that above XSS PoC doesn't work for me in Chrome (it does work in Firefox). Since it's a `data:` URI the origin is stripped upon the browser redirecting to it so the harm is basically the same as open redirect. That being said, nice find - I'll triage this now.
activities.markdown_message: Hey @orange - that above XSS PoC doesn't work for me in Chrome (it does work in Firefox). Since it's a data: URI the origin is stripped upon the browser redirecting to it so the harm is basically the same as open redirect. That being said, nice find - I'll triage this now.

activities.message: ok, Thanks : )
activities.markdown_message: ok, Thanks : )

activities.message: As an update - this is in a third party we utilize (Exact Target). Since the vulnerability isn't actually in our systems/code we're working on reaching out to them to get this fix. This may take some time since the actual fix is out of our hands. Will keep you update on the progress!
activities.markdown_message: As an update - this is in a third party we utilize (Exact Target). Since the vulnerability isn't actually in our systems/code we're working on reaching out to them to get this fix. This may take some time since the actual fix is out of our hands. Will keep you update on the progress!

activities.message:
Hey @orange,

Thanks for your patience on this. I've looked into this and it appears that we are still waiting on the confirmation from the vendor. As soon as we get the confirmation back, we will let you know.

Thanks again,
-mike

activities.message: Pushing into public disclosure now, sorry for the delay and thanks for the report! A quick note for people reading this now, this report was submitted before both `*.et.uber.com` and open redirects  were taken out of scope on `4/11/2016`, they are both now out of scope.

activities.message:
Although it is for a long time.
I just learn a trick can be used in this scenario and it can cause XSS not just Open Redirect.

Refer from:
https://habrahabr.ru/company/pt/blog/247709/

<?php header("Location: //xxxx:1/" ?>
<script>alert(document.domain)</script>;

It can be work in the latest version of Firefox.

Just share it to you :)
